author: hndrewaall
content: does relying on all clients agreeing make critical infra (exchanges) more fragile as a bug in any one of them could DoS?

author: eccentricexit
content:
The opposite as you do not rely on all clients agreeing.

All clients do not need to agree for the chain to make progress, only 51% of the stake/hashpower is required (under Gasper and Nakamoto consensus (bitcoin). 
2/3 of the stake to finalize under Gasper, which comes naturally due to inactivity leak self healing.
Example: If Ethereum had only geth during the Shanghai attacks things would've been much worse. Luckily, Parity/OpenEthereum was there.

author: hndrewaall
content: thats the network, not an exchange configured to stop processing transactions in the event of inconsistency

author: eccentricexit
content:
Oh I see what you mean.
Yes it would be more fragile than using consensus from multiple client implementations as one buggy implementation would cause everything to stop. In other words, the setup would be as if the network had a single client implementation.

author: hndrewaall
content: i mean it might be an acceptable risk if the alternative is having to roll back

author: eccentricexit
content: You may be interested in this as well: https://github.com/karalabe/minority

author: eccentricexit
content:
In fact, channel, please confirm my understanding:

In most current PoS based consensus protocols, 2/3rds need to behave properly so that the chain moves forward. Examples include: Avalanche's, Tendermint, Algorand, Ouroboros

Gasper is different: it requires 2/3rds of the stake to finalize but 51% is enough for the chain to make progress. 
Is this correct?
